snippet: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.
abstract: Italian porcelain tableware maker Richard Ginori is searching for a buyer after declaring bankruptcy, leaving more than 300 workers facing unemployment; how the company, founded in 1735, went bankrupt is subject of considerable debate, and highlights the larger problems faced by nearly all of Italy's small- and medium-size manufacturers at a time of global competition and domestic economic woes.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.

headline.seo: Richard Ginori, ‘the Ferrari of Porcelain,’ Struggles to Find a Buyer
headline.main: In Italy, a Factory Too Fragile for Its Time
headline.print_headline: ‘Ferrari of Porcelain’ Struggles to Find Buyer, Reflecting Hard Times in Italy
